text: The hotel is six stories high, a wall of glass and stucco Beach chairs are arrayed around the pool's edge; sunbathe lie sprawled across them. A short boardwalk leads toward Gulf of Mexico: the white sand, the blue water. Four young Americans are encamped near the pool's edge; they're all in their early twenties. AMY lies face down o chaise, eyes shut, a cooler beside her. She's petite, wit short blond hair, her skin pinkly sunburned. ERIC sits in the chair beside her, studying the Cliff Not for The Canterbury Tales. He's leanly muscular, with dark curly hair. Other Cliff Notes lie scattered beneath his chair: Antigone, A Separate Peace, Hea rt of Darkness, 19 JEFF and STACY sit on the far side of the cooler; they're playing gin. Stacy, too, is petite, with short hair, thou hers,. is dark. She's wearing a pale blue bikini, and has beer bottle in her hand. She looks a little bored. Jeff is tall, scrawny. Like Eric, he has a pair of swim trunks on, and is deeply tanned. He's very focused, frown down at his cards.
We should play War. It's more fun. Jeff takes a card from his hand, lays it down on the tabl
That's not even a game.
Sure it is. I'll teach you. She starts-to fold her hand,'but Jeff shakes his head.

I know how to play. I mean it's just chance--there's no skill involved. Stacy frowns down at her hand, silenced. She picks a card from the deck, immediately discards it. Jeff snatches it lays down one of his own. Stacy stares at it in dismay.
But I keep losing. 2.
'Cause you're not concentrating.
I wouldn't have to concentrate if we played War.
Exactly. So where's the fun?
I'd win sometimes. It's not fun if we both can't win.
But it's not winning if it's just chance.
Of course it is. If we flipped a coin, and I called heads, and it--
Fuck..;this.. shit. Eric throws the Canterbury Tales to the ground. Then he rises, steps to the cooler, pulls out a beer, carries it to his chair. Stacy watches as he takes a long swallow.

Maybe you should just be honest, sweetie. Eric doesn't even glance at her. He sips his beer again. STACY (cont'd) You could say: look, I don't know anything about these either, so now we're gonna read them together and sort of teach each other as we go. (turning to Jeff) Wouldn't you have loved that? To have a teacher who-- Amy speaks without opening her eyes, cutting Stacy off:
Why would they hire you if you haven't read the books?
I said I had. 3.
So maybe you should..
(appalled by the idea) The Canterbury Tales? You ever look at that shit?
I've read it.
Fuck off. It's not even English. Jeff watches Stacy take another card; she examines it, se it on the discard pile. Then, RECITING:

This world nys but a thurghfare ful of wo, and we been pilgrymes, passing to and fro. Deeth is an ende of every worldly soore. Eric and Stacy stare at Jeff in astonishment. Amy doesn't react. Jeff glances toward her. JEFF (cont'd) Sunscreen, Amy.
I'm fine. I've got a base.
You're burning. I can see it. She finally opens her eyes, lifts her head, peers at her shoulders. She presses at the pink skin.
I'm just flushed. It's too hot. Stacy leans forward, picks a second card off the deck. Je is focused on Amy; he doesn't notice.
You're hot because you're burning.
It's only been-- Stacy interrupts, speaking in a slightly SINGSONG fashion 4.
So there was this king, who lived in a castle. Amy turns, gives her a pained look.
Please don't.
But what he really wanted was a beach house.
Stop it. Both of you. Right now. They ignore her, ping-ponging quickly back and forth:
So he decided to move.
But the Queen didn't want to.
So he left by himself.
But he got lonely. Amy covers her ears with her hands, blocking out their voices, but then inmiediately reaches to feel for her earrings: one of them is missing.
Shit.
So he bought a dog.
But it had fleas.
I lost my earring.
So he gave it a bath.
But the dog caught. cold. Amy sits up, glancing about. Stacy and Eric keep going: 5.
So he gave it some medicine.
But it was the wrong kind.
So the dog died. Amy rises, steps toward the pool. Jeff lays down his card joins her beside the water. They both peer into it.

A young man is approaching down the boardwalk from the be carrying fins, a mask, a snorkel. He's in his early twenties: blond, crew-cut, very tall. His name is MATHIAS As he nears the pool, he stops, staring.
Eric and Stacy have risen to join Jeff and Amy; they're a peering into the water. Amy holds her remaining earring o to Eric and Stacy, showing them what it looks like.
He stands there, hesitating. Then he starts forward.
We glide just above the pool's pale blue bottom. A silver earring comes into view. Mathias's hand reaches for it.

The two couples have spread out around the pool's edge, searching for the earring. Mathias surfaces in front of A He holds out his hand, with the earring-in it; she stares startled, then crouches to take it.
Thank you so much. .Mathias nods. He starts to turn, as if to swim off, but stops him: 6.
Wait. . .want a beer? He waves toward their chairs, the cooler beside them.
Mathias and the two couples sit together, with their beer Amy's skin has turned deep red; Stacy is behind her, appl lotion to her shoulders. Eric is talking to Mathias:
We went sailing yesterday. Out toward Cozumel? And there were these seven foot fish, these huge--
Nurse sharks.
(he nods) Like thirty of them. A whole, you know, flock.
School.
The water was, I don't know, ten feet deep? And they were lying on the bottom, just waiting for somebody to come swimming by--
They're not dangerous. Eric turns, stares at Jeff.
You said they're sharks.
But they're not dangerous. They eat lobsters. Sea urchins. That sort of thing. Eric considers this, frowning. Then he takes a sip of bee He shrugs, turns back toward Mathias.
I wouldn't be snorkeling on my own.' That's all I'm saying. 7. When Mathias speaks, it's with a SLIGHT GERMAN ACCENT:
I wasn't on my own. I was with my brother. Jeff glances around the pool.
He's here? Mathias shakes his head.
He met a girl. They went away.
To?
It's a complicated story. They watch him, waiting for more, but nothing comes. Fina
You should hang with us, then. If you're on your own. (he glances at the others) Right? Everyone nods, smiling. Eric reaches into the cooler, pul out another beer, holds it toward Mathias.

There's a DJ, a dozen beer kegs. A few young men and wome are dancing beside a bonfire, but most of the crowd is scattered in small groups across the sand, TALKING, drink the firelight flickering off their faces. Stacy, Amy, Eric, Jeff and Mathias are sitting together; all have cups of beer. Stacy is between Eric's legs, lean against his chest. Amy, Jeff and Mathias sit cross-legged Everyone but Jeff and Mathias is a little drunk, and you hear it in their voices. Amy drains her cup, stands up, v unsteadily. She holds out her hand to Jeff.
Dance. Eric smiles, as if the idea of Jeff dancing were absurd. 8.
Jeff doesn't dance, Amy--he has no rhythm. Of all his many gifts, rhythm is not one.
That's not true. He played the trombone in high school. He won a prize. Eric seems startled by this, amused.
Seriously? Amy nods. She drains her beer, tosses the cup aside.
Jeff's won prizes for everything. His Mom has a whole room built just for them. Trophies and ribbons and plaques. He's a very accomplished young man. (she holds out her hand-to
You?
(he shakes his head) I don't dance on sand. Stacy makes a SNORTING sound.
Or grass. Or cement. Or carpet.
I dance on teak.
Teak?

It's a type of wood. Very rare. Find me a teak floor and I'll be a dancing fool. Amy shifts toward Mathias, holds out her hand. He stares it, then glances at Jeff. Before he can speak, Stacy push herself to her feet; she's almost as wobbly as Amy.
I'll dance. 9. They lurch off across the sand toward the bonfire. The bo watch them go. A beat, then Jeff glances at his watch.
I'm gonna head back. Eric gives him a look of disappointment,
You're kidding. Jeff seems STARTLED by this:
What?

How long is med school? Four years? Jeff nods. ERIC (cont'd) And then you got, whaddya call it, residency? Another nod. Eric turns toward Mathias. ERIC (cont'd) He's gonna be grinding away all that time. Sleepless. Fucking miserable. And know what? He's gonna look back on this night, us right here, and he's gonna say to himself, shit, I wish I'd--

Gone to bed earlier. Eric stares at him; this wasn't the direction he was head JEFF (cont'd) If I'm gonna be so short on sleep, I should get as.much as I can now, don't you think? He stands up, brushes the sand from his shorts. Eric shru lifts his cup toward him.
All work and no play-- 10.

Makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise. With that, Jeff nods good night to them, then starts off toward the hotel. Eric and Mathias turn back toward the bonfire. They sit in silence, watching the girls dance. After a moment, Amy staggers away from the other dancers, toward a group of young men, drinking together in the shadows. She reaches down, pulls one of them to his feet, starts to drag him back toward the bonfire. The young man is tall, with long blond hair. He LAUGHS, tries to free himself, but Amy is insistent; she keeps pulling at him, and finally he surrenders. They begin to dance. Stacy is dancing on her own, eyes shut, oblivious. Mathias glances toward Eric. Eric shrugs.
Amy drifts sometimes, when she drinks.
Drifts?

Like a boat--she bumps into other boats. They continue to watch. Amy and her partner's dancing is becoming steadily more intimate, the gap between their bo narrowing, then disappearing altogether. Finally, Eric pushes himself to his feet.' ERIC (cont'd) Come on. Let's save everyone some grief. He starts. forward, followed by Mathias. They join Stacy Amy, and Eric subtly interrupts Amy's pas de deux. The bl haired young man disengages, drifts back toward his frien

It's quiet, the sun just breaking the horizon; the beach nearly empty. A handful of hotel employees are tidying up after the bonfire: carrying off the empty kegs, raking cl the rubbish-strewn sand. Gulls hover overhead, CAWING. 11. Jeff appears, running along the beach, his T-shirt soaked with sweat. He stops as he nears us, stands for a moment just above the line of surf, catching his breath, watchin the sun rise. Then he turns, starts toward the hotel.

A breakfast buffet: trays of pancakes, eggs, fresh fruit. There are a dozen tables beneath brightly colored umbrell Mathias is the only diner at this hour; he's dressed in j and a T-shirt. He studies a piece of paper as he eats.
You're up early. Mathias lifts his head: Jeff is standing there in his swe shirt, smiling down at him.
I have to catch a bus.

To? Mathias slides the sheet of paper toward him. Jeff bends look. There's a paragraph in German scrawled above a hand drawn map, with four place names: Cancun, Valladolid, Tizimin, Coba. A large X has been drawn to the west of Co

The girl my brother met was on her way to this place, to work. (he waves at the map) It's a dig--an archaeological dig. And he went with her. He left the map, saying I could come, too, if I got bored on my own. A beat; he watches Jeff examine the map. Then: MATHIAS (cont'd) Our flight leaves the day after tomorrow. I can wait and hope he returns in time.. Or I can go get him. It's a question of trusting him to do the right thing.
And you don't? 12.
Henrich doesn't think things through. He runs at them. He's... (he searches, shakes his
There's a word in English, but I can't remember it.
impetuous?
(he nods) So I have to be--
Responsible.
All our lives, the same story. Jeff.slides the map back toward him.
It's what? One of those pyramids?
(he shakes his head) An old mining camp.
De oro? 0 plata? Mathias just stares at him. JEFF (cont'd) You don't speak Spanish? Mathias shakes his head. JEFF (cont'd) So how will you find this place?

(he smiles, shrugs) Follow the m ap. Jeff frowns down at the map for a long beat. It seems as he's going to question the feasibility of this, but. then disengages instead, wiping at the sweat on his face.
Well, good luck. 13. Mathias nods his thanks, and Jeff turns, starts away from table. WE MOVE with him, across the terrace, into the:

It's completely empty at this hour, and eerily silent. Chairs are stacked on the tables. As Jeff enters, a waite moves past ham, carrying a pitcher of orange juice. Jeff stops, turns to watch through the window beside the door.
The waiter refills Mathias's glass. Mathias smiles, nods.
Jeff hesitates, wavering. Then he pushes open the door again, steps outside. We watch--
--as he approaches Mathias. There's the sound of someone RETCHING, COUGHING. This carries over into:

A rack with towels on it, a sink, a tub. Amy is crouched over the toilet, in underwear and a T-shirt, VOMITING. He skin is bright red. Jeff is standing in the tub, freshly showered, drying himself, watching. her. His running clot hang from a hook beside the door.
You okay? Amy doesn't answer. She COUGHS, spits. JEFF (cont'd) You don't have to come, you know.
I'm fine.
You don't look fine.
Thank you. That's very helpful. 14. She pushes herself to her feet, flushes the toilet, steps the sink, squeezes some toothpaste onto a toothbrush.
We'll be back by nightfall. You can just-- Amy is raising the brush to her mouth, but she stops, giv Jeff a look in the mirror.
You don't want me to come?
That's not what I'm saying.
So what're you saying?
You're hungover, under slept,
I'm not sunburned. Jeff stares at her, the deep red of her face. Then he shrugs, steps out of the tub, the towel around his waist.
.All right. My mistake. Amy bends over the sink, starts to brush her teeth.

A king-sized bed, a bureau, two night tables, a mini-frid Jeff emerges from-the bathroom, steps toward the bureau, starts to dress: boxers, jeans, T-shirt. A beat, then Amy shuffles out of the bathroom. She sits o the edge of the bed, starts to pull on a pair of shorts.
Pants. Amy stops, the shorts around her ankles.
I'll get too sweaty. 15. Jeff pulls a pair of khakis from the bureau, tosses them the bed beside her.

There's gonna be mosquitoes. He picks up a knapsack, steps to the mini-fridge, opens i door. Amy stares down at the khakis for a beat, then drop back onto the bed. She lies there, looking up at the ceiling, her shorts still caught around her ankles.
We don't even know this guy. Jeff slides two bottles of iced tea into the knapsack. There's a plastic shopping bag beside the fridge, and he starts to dig through it.
And?
I just don't see why we have to go with him.
If you and I were traveling together, somewhere you didn't speak the language, and I'd vanished somehow, wouldn't you want someone to help find me?
Why would you vanish? Jeff turns, looks at her: this isn't the point.

Aren't you getting bored? Honestly. The beach, the pool, the beach, the pool. This'll be fun. An adventure. Jeff pulls two protein bars from the bag, a box of raisin plastic bag full of grapes; he drops them into the knapsa JEFF (cont'd) You said you wanted to go;hiking, didn't you? See the ruins. Amy is silent, unmoving, clearly not swayed. 16. JEFF (cont'd) Stay here, then. Seriously. There's no--
Why do you keep saying that?
It's like you'd rather I didn't-- A KNOCKING at the door, and she falls silent. Jeff rises, zipping shut the knapsack. He steps to the door, opens it Stacy and Eric are in the hall.
Ready? The both answer at the same time:
Amy's having second thoughts. Jeff doesn't want me to go. Stacy and Eric are silent; neither wants to get involved this. A beat, then Jeff SIGHS, glances at his watch.
Now or never, Any. .We're gonna miss the bus. Amy gives a loud GROAN, sits up, reaches for her khakis.

Only half the seats are occupied: tourists with their pac and cameras-and hats. Little TVs hang from the ceiling. We MOVE slowly down the aisle, passing Jeff and Amy first Amy is sound asleep, a camera hanging from her neck, a Pa hat in her lap. Jeff is beside her, bent low over a tour book, comparing its much more detailed map with the one Mathias's brother left behind. Next come Eric and Stacy, hunched together in their seats watching a Mexican soap opera on the little TV above them Stacy mimics the actors' exaggerated gestures, GIGGLING. Eric has the Cliff Notes for Hamlet in his lap, unopened. Finally, there's Mathias. The seat beside him is empty. He's staring out the window, his expression perfectly bla 17.

The town is very small: a dirt road lined with one- and t story buildings, some with thatched roofs. There's a grav turnaround, with a bus idling in it. Its door CREAKS open A dozen tourists emerge from the bus, blinking in the sunlight. Jeff, Amy, Stacy, Eric, and Mathias are among them. The boys have the knapsacks; the girls are wearing matching hats. Amy rubs at her face, stretching, waking u There's a souvenir stand at the town's entrance, with brightly colored blankets hanging from its walls. The tourists start toward it, leaving Jeff and the others bes the idling bus. They peer about, getting their bearings.
Now what? Mathias has his brother's note. He holds it out, pointing and they gather around him to look.
We take a cab. To here. WE SEE the map: there's a line drawn from Cancun to Coba, where another, shorter line moves westward. Mathias's fin moves along this shorter line, toward the X on the map.
How far?
Eighteen kilometers.
How many miles is that? They all glance at Jeff. He shrugs.
Eleven. A little more.
Then there'll be a path. Which we hike--four kilometers. The others look to Jeff again. He slings his pack.
Two and a half miles. 18. The tourists are vanishing into the town. The bus's door SQUEAKS shut.

I don't see any cabs. The bus eases into motion, CRUNCHING across the gravel, pulling out onto the road. Behind it, a yellow pickup tru is revealed. "TAXI" is hand-painted in black on its side. They start toward the truck. Its DRIVER is Mayan: short a heavy-set, with thick glasses. His eyes are shut; he's dozing behind the wheel. The truck's engine.is running, t windows shut tight against the heat. Jeff TAPS the window, and there's a burst of movement fro the truck's rear, as a dog springs up, BARKING and GROWLI They all leap back, the girls SHRIEKING. The dog is a mutt--small, but muscular. He's attached to cinder block by a short chain, which he throws himself against, slobbering, snapping at the air. They all stare at the dog; the girls LAUGH nervously, clutching each other. The driver has roused himself; he leans forward, rolls down his window, stares out at them.

Hola. The man gives him a somber nod; the dog keeps BARKING. Je takes the map from Mathias, then steps warily forward. JEFF (cont'd) Habla ingles usted? The man half-nods, half-shrugs. JEFF (cont'd) How much to drive us to here? He offers the map to the driver, who reaches to take it. man frowns at it. Then, in HEAVILY ACCENTED ENGLISH:
Why you go this place? Jeff struggles for a simple way to explain their mission. the back of the truck, the dog continues its frantic BARR
There are these ruins. This old mining camp? (MORE)
JEFF (cont'd) (he points toward Mathias) And his brother---
Fifteen dollar, I take you ruins.
To here? Jeff points at the map. The driver shakes his head.
This place no good. He holds the map back out toward Jeff. Jeff takes it, giv the man a puzzled look.
No good?

No good you go. Fifteen dollar I take you good place. You like, I promise. Jeff glances toward the others, as if for help. They all just stand there, watching. The dog won't stop BARRING. DRIVER (cont'd) I take you pyramid. Huy grande. Everyone happy. He smiles at Jeff; his teeth are large and thick-looking, black along the gums. Jeff pulls out his wallet. He remov a ten and a five, then points at the map.
How about we pay you fifteen dollars to go here? He holds the money out. The man doesn't even look at it.

I tell you no good. Still you go? His smile has disappeared; he seems angry suddenly, as if Jeff has somehow insulted him. Jeff hesitates, glancing toward the others again. Then, in a CONCILIATORY TONE:

We're looking for his brother. (he points toward Mathias) Su hermano? 20. The driver wrenches the door open, making Jeff and the ot flinch. He climbs out, still with that angry expression o his face, then leans into the back of the truck, grabs th dog's chain, unhooks it from the cinder block. He lifts the dog from the truck by the chain. Even dangli by its neck, the mutt continues to SNARL and snap at Jeff the others. They back away, and the man tosses the dog in the truck's cab, pushing the door shut. The dog throws it body against the window, slobbering and BARKING. The man turns toward Jeff, wiping his hands on his pants. Jeff tries again: JEFF (cont'd) I'm sure your ruins are better than these. It's just that we-- The driver cuts him off, holding out his hand, with that air of enraged disgust.
El dinero. Jeff gives him the money. Then the driver SLAPS the side the truck, gestures for them to climb into the back.

Below us, the yellow truck travels along a single-lane ro Jeff and the others are in its rear. There are fields on either side of the road, bordered by thick jungle. The truck reaches a fork in the road, bears left, angling toward the wall of jungle, into which it vanishes, the overhanging foliage blocking it from sight.

The road is dirt, heavily rutted. There's a small clearin beside it, with a path opening off it. The trees grow ove the path, forming a shady tunnel. WE HEAR birds calling, steady throb of insect life, but otherwise all is silent. A beat, then there's the sound of the TRUCK approaching, along with the dog's BARKING and GROWLING. The pickup appears, moving slowly, bouncing and swaying across the r The truck pulls into the little clearing, stops. Jeff and the others clamber out over its tailgate. 21. The dog is still lunging at them from behind the truck's window. Jeff gives the driver a wave.

Gracias, senor! The driver doesn't even look at him; he just pulls out on the road, heading back in the direction from which they c There are mosquitoes; Stacy starts to slap at herself. Je unslings his pack, pulls out a can of insect repellent. JEFF (cont'd) Here. He begins to spray her, then Eric. Amy is peering off aft the truck. They can still hear the dog's BARKING, but ver faintly now. Jeff finishes with Eric, starts in on Mathia
How do we get back? She points back down the road, toward the vanished truck. Jeff pauses in his spraying, considers for a moment. Then
The guidebook said you can always flag down a passing bus. So I--
There aren't going to be any buses on that road. Jeff nods; this seems obvious. He resumes spraying Mathia Eric and Stacy stand there, watching. AMY (cont'd) A bus couldn't even fit.
It also said you can hitch--
See any cars pass, Jeff? Jeff doesn't answer. He steps toward her, starts to spray her, too. She holds out her arms. AMY (cont'd) The whole time we were driving, you see even one?
Eric has his phone. Can't we just call someone? 22.

He's not gonna get a signal. Not way out here. They all turn to watch as Eric reaches into. his pack, pu out his cell phone, flips it open. He stares at it for a beat, then shakes his head, snaps it shut. Jeff finishes spraying Amy, starts in on himself.
They must-have a way to get supplies in.
Who?

The archaeologists. They must have a truck. Or access to a truck. When we find Mathias's brother, we can just ask them to take us all back to Coba. (turning to Mathias) Right? Mathias seems startled by the question.
I guess ...I mean, I-- He shrugs; he has no idea. Amy is still focused on Jeff:
We're stranded, aren't we? That's, like, a twenty mile walk we're gonna have to do. Through the jungle.
Eleven.
What? Jeff finishes with the insect repellent, crouches to slid the can back into his pack.
It's eleven miles.
There's no way that was eleven miles. 23. Jeff rises, slings his pack. He gives Amy a tired look.

Let's just find this place, okay? Then we can figure out how to get back. Amy is silent. Jeff turns to the others. JEFF (cont'd) Ready? Mathias and Eric nod, and the boys start down the path. A stands there, watching them go. Stacy steps toward her.'
Just go with it, honey. You'll see--it'll all work out. She hooks arms with her, pulls her into motion.

They hike in single file: first Jeff, then Eric, Mathias, Stacy, and Amy. The path is six feet wide, hard-packed di All around and above is the jungle: big-leafed plants, vi and creepers, immense trees. The path moves in snakelike curves; we can't see-very far either direction. They're all sweating, their shirts clinging to their bodies. The bugs continue to harass the
So-there was this girl who bought a piano. Amy gives a loud MOAN.
But she didn't know how to play.
So she signed up for lessons.
But she couldn't afford them. Stacy reaches, taps Mathias's shoulder.

You can play, too. If you want. 24. Mathias glances back at her. STACY (cont'd) It's easy. Someone says So, then you say But. It's like catch, only without a ball. (to Eric) So she got a job in a factory.
But was fired for being late. Amy takes off her hat, wipes the sweat from her face.
It's annoying.
So she became a prostitute.
It's tedious and boring. And once they start, it's impossible to get them to stop.
But she fell in love with her first client. Amy puts her hat back on. She looks hot, sweaty, tired.
How much farther? Mathias peers down at his brother's note. Stacy and Eric continue with their game.
We cross a stream. Then So she asked him to marry there'll be a path, branching her. off to our left. If we see a village, we've gone too far. AMY (cont'd) ERIC A village? But he was already married.
A Mayan village. So she begged him to get a divorce. AMY (cont'd) ERIC Will they have air But he was in love with his conditioning? wife. 25. Mathias shrugs, returns the note to his pocket.
It just says there's a So she decided to kill her. village. AMY (cont'd) I think we should go see it.
Me, too.
I think we should--- Jeff stops suddenly, pointing.

The stream. Thirty feet in front of them, the trail dips toward a sma stream, studded with boulders. It resumes on the far bank rising gradually uphill in a long straightaway. The strea is slow moving, the water dark brown. Eric SNIFFS the air
Fucking smells.
They must use it as a latrine.
Who?

The village. The Mayans. They start toward it, gingerly, the girls covering their noses. Jeff crosses the stream, hopping from boulder to boulder, and the others follow. Stacy almost falls in; sh only catches her balance at the final instant, YELPING. Jeff is already starting up the trail, searching for the turnoff. There's no sign of it; the dense foliage extends unbroken as far as the eye can see. He turns to Mathias. JEFF (cont'd) How far past the stream?.
Right after, it says. 26. They stand there in a loose group, staring at the trees. Eric pulls a bottle of water from his pack, takes a swall then passes it to Stacy. Amy lifts her arm, points.

Look. Up the trail, sixty feet away, stand two small Mayan boys they seem to have materialized out of the air. They're te years old, shirtless, scrawny, dark-haired. one of them i holding a bicycle by its handlebars; it doesn't have a se AMY (cont'd) Maybe they can guide us. Stacy smiles toward the boys; she waves, CALLS OUT:
The boys just stand there, staring at them, silent, their expressions wary, even frightened. One of them leans to whisper something to the other, who nods.

Why don't we-- He stops, noticing Mathias. The German is staring toward edge of the trail, where a large bush sits. one of its fronds is very slowly dropping toward them, pulling itsel free of the soil. Mathias steps forward, tugs at a second frond, which slip easily from the dirt. He tosses it aside, reaches for another frond: this, too, slips free. Someone has pushed them into the earth, arranging them to look like a bush. Mathias pulls a fourth frond free, then a fifth, and an opening is revealed in the brush, a narrow path winding i way off through the trees. They stand there a beat, stari at it. Then there's a SQUEAKING SOUND, and they all turn.
one of the boys is hurriedly pedaling off, bent low over bicycle's handlebars. His companion remains behind, stari toward us with a look of obvious anxiety.
Amy turns to Jeff; so do the others. 27.
Why was it covered? Jeff lifts his hands: how should he know?

Maybe it's not the right path. NO one speaks. They keep staring from the boy to the newl revealed path, trying to make sense of it. WE can still H the squeaking of the bicycle, growing steadily fainter.
It's on the map.
It's a hand-drawn map, Jeff.

And it was hidden. Why would it be hidden? Jeff steps forward, shields his eyes, tries to peer into dimness of the narrow path. Then he glances back toward t little boy, who continues to stand there, watching them.
Maybe the archaeologists don't want people to find the mine.
Because? Jeff has to think. Finally:

Maybe they've dug up something valuable. Emeralds or something. Or silver. Whatever they were mining in the first place. And they don't want anyone to come rob them. So they've asked the Mayans to help keep people away. He falls into silence, staring at the boy. No one appears very convinced by his theory, not even Jeff. He shrugs. JEFF (cont'd) How much farther is it? Mathias takes the map from his pocket again, glances at i 28.
Not far.
Be silly to stop now, don't you think? No one answers; no one moves.
This just feels weird, Jeff. Jeff SIGHS, fighting to suppress his impatience with her.

We'll pull you up. Then we'll see. He starts toward the windlass again.

The rope jerks, and she begins to rise. She kicks her leg lifts her left arm over head, wrenches it free of the sli so that only her right arm remains hooked. She switches t lamp from her right hand to her left, then slips complete free of,the sling, the lamp fluttering out as she drops.

Almost totally dark, just a faint fall of light from abov Mathias is a dim shape on the floor of the shaft. Stacy lands beside him--heavily, awkwardly--the glass from his shattered lamp CRUNCHING beneath her. 54. She loses her balance, pitches forward, onto his body. MATHIAS makes a terrible SHRIEKING sound, pure pain, flai his arms. Stacy struggles to right herself.
I'm sorry. Oh, God. I'm so sorry. She pulls herself into a crouch, staring down at him thro the dimness, his SHRIEK fading to a steady MOANING.
Jeff, Amy, and Eric have rushed to the shaft; they're pee into it. There's only darkness beneath them. Eric SHOUTS:
Stacy...? Stacy's voice rises toward them, sounding. very FAR AWAY:
I didn't want him to be alone.
What happened to the lamp?
It blew out. Jeff turns from the shaft, picks up the box of matches. H yanks off his shirt, ties the box inside it, then steps b to the edge of the hole. He CALLS down to Stacy:
I'm dropping the matches. Okay?

Okay. Jeff holds the knotted bundle over the shaft, lets it go. falls into the darkness. A long beat, and then, very soft WE HEAR the thump as it lands. STACY (O.S.) (cont'd) Got it. The three of them stare into the hole, waiting for the li 55.

There's the RASP of a match, its flickering flame, then t stronger illumination of the lamp as Stacy lights its wic Mathias lies on his back before her, silent now, motionle his eyes shut. Stacy bends toward him, WHISPERS:

Mathias...? He doesn't respond; it's hard to tell if he's conscious. Stacy lifts the lamp, peers about the shaft. The vine has taken root even at this depth, its flowers and leaves pal the point of translucence. Beyond Mathias, there's an opening in the dirt wall, anot shaft cutting perpendicularly into the earth. Its roof is supported by a stone archway, intricately carved. Stacy rises, as if to investigate, but then winces, nearly fall She peers down at her right leg. A large piece of glass i imbedded there, just beneath her knee. it's the size of a playing card, gently concave,'dark with her blood. She reaches and, grimacing, pulls it from her body.
Jeff is at the windlass, hurriedly cranking the rope back Eric and Amy stand watching.
We need fifteen feet. Twenty to be safe. No one speaks. The windlass turns with that steady CREAKI but it's higher-pitched now, with no weight on the rope. JEFF (cont'd) Come on. Think. How can we--
The clothes? From the backpacks? We could knot them together?
Would they hold? Eric frowns, uncertain. Jeff finishes with the rope, stan there, catching his breath. Stacy's,voice rises toward th from the shaft: 56.
I cut my knee. Eric hurries to the shaft, followed by Jeff and Amy. They peer over its edge, toward Stacy, so far beneath them, in flickering circle of lamp light.
Bad?
My shoe's full of blood.
Put pressure on it. Use my shirt. They all stare down at her, waiting.

Stacy is crouched beside Mathias, pressing Jeff's T-shirt her wound. Her khakis and tennis shoe are dark with blood there's a lot of it. She isn't watching Mathias; he start her when he opens his eyes and speaks:
My...legs... His voice is faint and RASPY; we can hear his pain in it. Stacy leans toward him, tries to smile reassuringly.
Hey...
Can't... move ...my...legs... Stacy turns to look: his legs are lying at an odd angle, if he were a doll that had been carelessly tossed there.
Jeff, Eric and Amy, still watching; Jeff turns to the oth
What about the tents? We could take one down, cut the nylon into strips. Eric and Amy glance toward the tents, debating. 57.
Would it be strong enough?
we can braid them--three strips for each section. Then knot the sections together, for strength. Before either of them can respond, Stacy's voice emerges the shaft, sounding SCARED:
I think he broke his back. They fall silent, staring down at her. STACY (O.S.) (cont'd) He can't move his legs. And it smells.
Smells?
Like he lost his bowels. His bladder.
(very quietly) Oh no. Please no. Jeff turns to her.
How can we make a backboard? Amy starts to shake her head, looking horrified.
No, Jeff. No way. We can't move him.
One of the frames from the backpacks? And the tent poles. There's tape in the orange tent. He doesn't wait for a response; he leans over the shaft,
JEFF (cont'd) We have to builda backboard, Stacy. It might take a while. 58. There's a long hesitation, as if Stacy is searching for s alternative. Then, still sounding FRIGHTENED and FARAWAY:
Okay. Amy is shaking her head, growing FRANTIC:
We'll make it worse. Well jostle him, and he'll-- Jeff turns toward her, with a hint of EXASPERATION:
We can't just leave him down there. You know that, don't you? She starts to back away, toward the edge of the clearing.
we have to tell them.
Who?
The Mayans. We have to tell them what's happened. Jeff gives her an incredulous look. She keeps retreating; she's almost at the path. AMY (cont'd) They can send for help.
They're not gonna---
We have to may. We have to-- She spins, starts off at a run, vanishing down the trail. Jeff calls after her, SHOUTING:
Amy! But she's gone. Jeff turns to Eric. JEFF (cont'd) Stay here. 59. And then he, too, is running.

The Mayans have established their campsite on the edge of jungle. Two women are beside a campfire, plucking a pair chickens. WE SEE other campsites in the distance, other campfires, hugging the jungle's margin, surrounding the h Three men sit in the center of the clearing, facing the hillside, their bows in their laps. They rise suddenly, peering up the trail. The women pause in their labor, als staring. The campsite goes QUIET.
Amy is sprinting toward us down the trail. Jeff is ten ya behind her, also running.

The three Mayans nock arrows. Two other men step forward join them. One has a bow; the other is the bald Mayan, wi the pistol. He unholsters it, and--as Amy reaches the bot of the trail--raises it, aiming at her chest. Amy stops just short of the clearing: sweating, breathles scared-looking. She lifts her hands, palms-up, beseeching
Help us. Please. Someone's been hurt. He-- Jeff comes to a halt, five feet behind her.
They can't understand you. She turns, her voice quickened with PANIC:
Say it in Spanish. Tell them he--
They don't speak Spanish.

Try it. You have to try. 60. She spins back toward the Mayans, takes a step into the clearing. The bald man SHOUTS at her, a single short sentence in MAYAN. Amy holds out her hands to him. AMY (cont'd) Espanol? Habla Espanol? Jeff steps forward, grabs her elbow.
They killed Henrich. Why would- Amy tries to tug free, but he won't let her. She starts t SHOUT at the Mayans:

Help usi We need help! The Mayans just stare at her, their weapons raised, their faces expressionless. one of them is much younger than th others, almost a boy. He says something in MAYAN to the b man, and the bald man shakes his head. Amy begins to CRY. Jeff pulls at her elbow.
We have to get back. Amy turns toward him, her face smeared with tears.
I didn't want to come. I told you we shouldn't. I said-- Jeff tightens his grip on her arm, gives her a little sha as if to wake her up.
Listen to me. Mathias needs our help. Right now. He--

We shouldn't even be here. Why did you say we'd come? (she wipes at her tears) You have to do something. (rising toward a shout) You have to! It's your fault. It's all your-- Jeff shakes her again, more roughly, his voice like a sla 61.

YD-q stepped onto the hill. Amy stares at him, startled into silence. JEFF (cont'd) They wouldn't have forced us up it if you hadn't. He holds her eyes, making sure she understands. Then: JEFF (cont'd) Now let's go, okay? He starts to pull her back toward the trail. She allows herself to be led; she's begun to CRY again:
I didn't know. I just-- She's growing increasingly upset, almost SOBBING. She tri to turn back toward the Mayans again, but Jeff won't let AMY (cont'd) They have to help us.
They're not going to.

They have to. She wrenches herself free, stumbles, falls into the vines beside the trail. Jeff reaches for her, but she kicks awa from him, grabbing at the vines, scrambling to her feet. As she rises, she yanks up a tendril, a clot of earth han from its roots. She SCREAMS, spinning toward the clearing AMY (cont'd)

head_text.subj: WHY WON'T YOU FUCKING HELP US

text: --and throws the tendril at the Mayans. They scramble backward, with surprising panic, SHOUTING. The youngest o them is too slow: the length of vine hits him in the leg. He stares down at the tendril in shock. The others back hurriedly away from him. Two of them continue to point their weapons at Amy, but the bald man one of the other bowmen are aiming at the young Mayan now There's SHOUTING from the tree line. The entire campsite on its feet; a woman begins to SCREAM. 62. She's in her,forties, short and stout, and she starts for into the clearing, arms stretched toward the young Mayan. Two of the other women grab her, hold her back. The bald Mayan starts to ADDRESS the young man, pointing the hillside. The short woman keeps SCREAMING, flailing, trying to break free. The young Mayan looks at her, then the bald man. He speaks in MAYAN, a brief burst of words. The bald man shakes his head, points up the hill again, h pistol aimed at the young man's chest. The short woman is WAILING, eyes shut. The young Mayan takes a step toward h CALLING what seems to be her name. The bald man SHOUTS at him, but the young Mayan ignores h takes a second step, then a third. The bowmen are all aim at him now, and suddenly, everyone seems to be YELLING. The young Mayan takes a fifth step, holding out his arms toward the WAILING woman, CALLING to her. The bald man FIRES, shooting him in the head. At the same instant, the bowmen let their arrows fly, the shafts THUMPING into the young man's chest, burying themselves to the fletches. The clearing goes still; the only sound is the woman's st WAILING. Then the bald man swings his pistol toward Amy a Jeffs he SHOUTS in MAYAN at them. The other Mayans nock fresh arrows, draw their bows. Jeff takes a step backward, half-raising his hands. Amy j stands there, her eyes on the young Mayan's motionless bo

(no reaction) AY. She turns, finally. She looks horrified, stupefied; her hands are burned a deep red from the vine's sap. Jeff wav her up the hill. She stares at him for another beat, and then, without a word, starts to climb the trail. Jeff hesitates, watching the Mayans: the bloodied corpse, the raised weapons, the KEENING woman. Then he, too, turn and hurries off up the trail.

Amy, Jeff, and Eric have taken down the blue tent; its contents lie tumbled in a pile in the little clearing. Al three of them look sun struck, sweat-stained, worn out. 63. Eric is using a knife to cut long strips from the blue ny Amy is braiding three of the strips together. Jeff has on of the backpack frames, the roll of duct tape, and some o the poles from the tent; he's making a backboard.

Maybe we could use it as a weapon, you know? Wrap it around some stones or something. And throw them, like grenades. I mean, if they're that scared of it-- Jeff tears off a piece of tape with his teeth.

They have guns, Eric. And bows. What do you think they'll do if we start throwing the vine at them? Eric is silenced by this. He cuts another long strip of nylon, passes it to Amy. But he can't seem to stop himsel from talking: ERIC. So you figure it's, what? Sacred or something? Like, you touch it and you have to die? Amy begins to cry suddenly--a SOB, quickly suppressed. Je and Eric both turn to look at her. The vine's sap has scarred her hands and arms almost to the elbows. She wipe her eyes, takes a deep breath, shakes her head.
I'm okay. But she doesn't look it. Jeff removes his hat, holds it o Amy just stares at it; he nods for her to take it.

Come on. You're burning. She reaches for the hat, puts it on, then wipes at her ey again. Jeff leans forward, touches her. JEFF (cont'd) We're gonna get through this. All right? We'll pull them up. And then ...I don't know--we'll figure things out. it has to rain at some point. And maybe we can snare some birds. Or-- 64. The electronic RINGING sounds once more from the bottom o the shaft. They all turn to stare.

The oil lamp has begun to smoke, adding a haze to the lig Stacy is beside Mathias, holding his hand. She's still pressing Jeff's shirt to her wound. The RING sounds again Mathias turns his head, peers toward the shaft cut into t dirt wall to his left: that's where it's coming from. Sta reaches to pick up the lamp, rises to her feet. Another RING. Jeff SHOUTS down from above:
Stacy...? Stacy ignores him; she limps around Mathias, starts towar the opening. She hesitates at the mouth of the shaft, lifting her lamp to see better. There's another RING.

The lamp's light doesn't penetrate very far, but WE can S that the vine has taken root here with great avidity: it grows thickly on the walls, floor and roof. There's a ste draft coming toward us, and the plant shifts in it, RUSTL
Stacy stands there, looking scared. There's another RING.
Can you see it? Stacy lifts her head, SHOUTS:

No. She keeps peering into the shadows, not moving. The ringi falls SILENT. Stacy turns, hobbles back toward Mathias, a the light shudders, dims for a moment. She squints at it: the oil is nearly gone. She SHOUTS up to the others: STACY (cont'd) The lamp's almost out of oil.
Then blow it out. 65. Stacy seems terrified by this.
Blow it out?

We'll need it when we come down. To get him on the backboard. Stacy drops into a crouch beside Mathias, sets the lamp d before her, stares at it. She clearly doesn't want to blo it out. Mathias watches her, silent. JEFF (O.S.) (cont'd) All right? Stacy leans forward, lifts the lamp's glass chimney, blow out the flame, dropping the shaft into darkness.

The.sun is just touching the horizon, the sky turning red Th ey've tied the braids of nylon onto the rope, attached finished backboard to them. It rests beside the shaft, padded with one-of the archaeologist's sleeping bags. Jeff and Eric remove their belts, drop them onto the backboard. They step to the windlass, lean against its ha crank, the rope going taut. Amy stands by the shaft, gathering her courage. Then she reaches for the backboard
Mathias and Stacy are two dim shapes in the darkness. The windlass begins its CREAKING. A long beat, and then:
Stacy?
What?

Light the lamp! Stacy shifts; once again, there's the RASP of a match, th the stronger illumination of the lamp as she lights its w Mathias's eyes are shut; there's a deep RAGGEDNESS to his breathing. Stacy looks upward. 66.
The backboard is dropping toward us. Above it, the light already fading from the sky.
Stacy rises to her feet, lifting the lamp.
She's dropping slowly down the shaft, clenching the nylon braids, her eyes tightly shut: terrified. The backboard sways, pendulum-like, as it descends, almost touching the vine-covered walls.

When the backboard comes within reach, Stacy grabs it, pulling it to the-right, so that it will come to rest at Mathias's side. But then, with three feet still to go, it jerks to a halt, almost toppling Amy from her perch. A beat, and Jeff's voice comes toward them from above:
Have you reached them?
Almost. A few more feet.
How many? Amy leans, peers down at Mathias's broken body.
I don't know. Three?
we're out of rope. (a beat) Can you still do it? Amy looks at Stacy; neither speaks. Finally, QUIETLY:

We'll have to send it back up, I guess. 67. Amy doesn't answer. She shifts her weight, and the backbo starts to swing. Stacy reaches to steady it. STACY (cont'd) Blow out the lamp. Wait here in the dark. Amy is silent, staring down at Mathias's still form; it's obvious she doesn't want to do this. STACY (cont'd) Or we could try to lift him, maybe. More silence. Stacy persists: STACY (cont'd) One of us at his shoulders. The other his feet.
If he twists--

It's only a few feet. /"- Once more, Amy is silent. Stacy lifts the lamp, exami it, the diminishing pool of oil. STACY (cont'.d) We have to decide. The light's not going to last. Jeff's voice comes toward them from above again:
Amy...? They both look up; the sky has grown too dark to see him. Amy hesitates one beat more, then YELLS:

We're gonna try itt She climbs off the backboard, crouches beside Mathias. St sets down the lamp. AMY (cont'd) Mathias...? She touches his shoulder, and he opens his eyes, stares a her. He looks haggard, ashen. 10111.. 68. AMY (cont'd) We're going to lift you, okay? We're going to hoist you up and out. Mathias stares from her to the backboard to Stacy. He shu his eyes. Amy stands up, drags the belts off the backboar drops them next to the lamp. She positions herself behind Mathias's head; Stacy hobbles to his feet, limping. AMY (cont'd) His hips. Stacy hesitates, looking doubtful.
You sure?
If you lift from his feet, he'll bend at the waist.
But if I lift at his hips, won't he arch his back? They both stare down at Mathis, imagining these two diffe scenarios. Amy glances toward the lamp, its dwindling oil

His knees. Stacy crouches by Mathias's knees, a little off balance, favoring her wounded leg. Amy bends, sliding her hands un his shoulders. Mathias GROANS, and Stacy starts to pull away, but Amy shakes her head. AMY (cont'd) Quickly. On three. They count together:
One ... two.-,.three. They lift, and Mathias immediately starts to SCREAM. His body sags at the waist; he begins to thrash his arms. Sta starts to set him down, but Amy shakes her head, SHOUTS:

No! 69. Stacy's wounded leg is hindering her; she can't keep up w Amy. Mathias's shoulders are level with the backboard, bu his knees are still a good foot beneath it. He keeps SCREAMING. The bend at his waist increases. AMY (cont'd) Lift I Stacy tries to hoist him higher, lunging, his torso twist his SCREAMS going LOUDER. His right arm, hits the backboa sends it swinging. The girls toss him toward it.
The sun has set. There's a half moon, giving us just enou light to dimly see Eric and Jeff peering into the shaft. Mathias's SCREAMS echo up toward them.

Mathias has fallen silent. He lies on the backboard, eyes clenched, sweat beading his forehead. Stacy is trying not to cry. She watches Amy buckle the tw belts together, then drape them over Mathias's chest, kno them tight. Amy strips off her own belt, gestures for Sta to do the same. She buckles these together, too.

I have to pee. She limps toward the wall, lowers her pants, gingerly crouches. She stares toward the other shaft as she pees: its stone archway, the shifting shadows, the vine rustlin softly in the steady draught. Amy binds Mathias at his thighs. She WHISPERS to him:

You okay? She waits, but he doesn't respond. His eyes remain shut. Stacy rises, buttoning her pants, limps back toward Amy. She's on the edge of tears, is working hard to fight them off. Amy lifts her head, SHOUTS up to Jeff: AMY (cont'd) Pull him up! 70. A moment's pause, then the windlass begins to CREAK once more. The backboard slowly rises, swaying gently. They watch it climb away from them. Amy holds out her-hand. ANY (cont'd) Here. Stacy just stares at her, not understanding. Amy nods at lamp: the oil is gone. AMY (cont'd) It's gonna go out. And it's true: as Stacy reaches for Amy's hand, the light suddenly flickers, dims, drops them into darkness.

The Mayans are settling into sleep at their campsite. Thr of the men remain on guard duty in the clearing, facing t hillside, their backs to the fire. The young Mayan's corp still lies in the dirt, fifteen feet in front of them. Th firelight throws shadows across his bloodied body.

The windlass CREAKS loudly as Eric and Jeff work to wind the rope. Stacy has already been pulled up from the hole. She's sitting beside Mathias, who's lying on the backboar on the edge of the clearing, by the orange tent. Amy emerges from the shaft, dangling beneath the sawhorse Jeff holds the rope taut while Eric steps to the hole, pu Amy toward him. Stacy watches from beside the backboard. Mathias's eyes are shut, his breathing ROUGH with phlegm. No one speaks. Once Amy is free of the sling, they all mo to the backboard. Eric takes Stacy's-hand; Jeff crouches, starts to undo the belts.
Shouldn't we carry him into the tent first? Jeff pulls free the first belt, shifts to the second one.
We can't.
Because? 71.
He's gonna keep leaking urine.
But we can't just leave him out in the open.

We'll rig a shelter. With what's left of the blue tent. Jeff pulls the second belt free. Mathias's eyes remain sh JEFF (cont'd) One of us should stay on watch while the others sleep. Two hour shifts. He reaches for his knapsack, unzips it. He pulls out a li bottle of water. JEFF (cont'd) .Once it's light, we'll figure out how much water we have, and how to ration it. Food, too. For now, I think we should each just take a single swig. He uncaps the bottle, hands it to Amy. He watches her dri from it. When she's done, she passes it to Stacy. JEFF (cont'd) Eric and I'll build the shelter,. then I'll take the first shift. You two should try to sleep. Stacy takes her single sip, passes the bottle to Eric.

Stacy and Amy have pushed the camping supplies into a pil along the tent's rear wall. Stacy pulls off her pants, be to examine her wound in the darkness. Amy is beside her, lying on her side. A beat of silence. Then, WHISPERING:
Amy? what? 72.
We shouldn't have lifted him, should we? Amy reaches, pats Stacy's hand.
Shh.
He's never gonna walk again.. He's--

Don't, Stacy. Don't talk. It'll only make things worse. Stacy falls silent. AMY (cont'd) Just go to sleep, okay? Let's try to go to sleep. Stacy lies down next to Amy, in her-underwear and T-shirt They huddle close together in the darkness.

Eric is building a tiny lean-to for Mathias, using the du tape, the leftover nylon and poles from the blue tent. Je crouches over the backboard. He starts to cut Mathias's jeans off him with the knife. Mathias's eyes remain shut.
What're you doing?
We have to keep him clean. He slices the jeans, from ankle to hip, first one leg, th the other, struggling not to jostle Mathias's body. JEFF (cont'd) That's how it'll happen, I think. if it does.
If what does? Jeff slides the soiled strips of-denim out from under Mathias's body, tosses them aside. He LOWERS his voice:. 73.
If he dies here. infection. Blood poisoning--something like that. Eric seems startled by this.
You think he's gonna die?

(he shrugs) His back is broken. Who knows what else. Eric is silent, motionless, the tape in his hand. Mathias BREATHING seems to be getting steadily worse. Jeff bends cut off his boxers, first one leg, then the other. He tos the soiled fabric aside. JEFF (cont'd) We should go back down in the morning.
Down?
Into the shaft. Try to find the phone again.
There's no oil for the lamp. Jeff waves toward the orange tent.

There's tequila. We could pour it on some of the clothes, tie them around one of these poles, make a torch. A sleeping bag is lying in the clearing among the strips nylon and aluminum poles. Jeff steps over to pick it up. JEFF (cont'd) Without the phone, he's dead. If we have to wait for someone to come searching... He shakes his head. Then he leans forward and carefully drapes the sleeping bag across Mathias's broken body. 74.

The orange nylon is just starting to glow with the sun's arrival. Stacy and Eric lie beneath one of the sleeping bags, Eric's head on her shoulder. Jeff lies curled on hi side, a few feet away, still shirtless. Jeff's eyes open. He sits up, stares about, then reaches one of the backpacks. He quietly digs through it till he finds a T-shirt. He sniffs at it, then pulls it on.

Mathias lies on his backboard, eyes shut, his breathing s sounding THICK WITH PHLEGM. Amy sits beside him, hunched into herself, half drowsing. She lifts her head as Jeff emerges from the tent, stares at him.
How is he?
The same.
And you?
(she shrugs) Tired. Thirsty. Hungry.

Once the others are up, we'll have some water. His face is stubbled, sweat-stained. He looks ragged; the both do. He steps to the opposite side of the clearing, unzips, begins to urinate, with his back to Amy.

The vine covers everything, tangled and matted, with thos odd, knoll-like growths scattered among it. The nearest-i thirty feet away. its leaves are swaying slightly in a fa breeze, and WE SEE a flash of yellowish white beneath the 75.
Jeff finishes, shakes, zips, then steps out into the vine wading toward the tiny mound. Amy remains beside the backboard; she watches him crouch, part the tendrils, sta
What is it? Jeff gestures for her to approach. When she reaches him, leans forward, pulls aside the vines. WE SEE a man's skul a loose tumble of bones. Amy INHALES sharply, recoiling.

Bodies. All of them. He waves across the hilltop, at the other mounds: there a more than a dozen. Amy takes them in. The light is gainin strength, the green leaves seeming to shine in it, the re flowers to glow. Jeff's face assumes a puzzled expression JEFF (cont'd) Where are the birds?
Birds?
it's dawn--there should be birds. They both stare off across the hillside: so quiet, so sti

Stacy opens her eyes. She lies there, struggling to orien herself, with Eric on her shoulder. She starts to roll on her side, then stops, looking confused. She reaches under the sleeping bag, toward her leg, her confusion changing to alarm. She site up, jarring Eric awake, and throws back the sleeping bag.
(BEFUDDLED)

What...? The vine has grown dramatically during the night, reachin out from the pile of supplies at the rear of the tent to spread across Stacy's right leg, almost to her waist. She sits up, tries to push it off her. 76.

Oh my god... The vine is clinging to her; she has to tear it, the sap shining slickly on her hands, visibly beginning to burn t skin. She yanks at the tendrils, tossing them aside. STACY (cont'd) Help me. Eric sits up, still only half-awake. He just stares. STACY (cont'd). It's inside me... It's true: one of the tendrils has pushed its way into th wound on her leg, widening it, thrusting itself a full th inches into her body, like a thick finger. STACY (cont.'d) Oh, Jesus--it's fucking inside me. She tries to pull the tendril out, but she's too panicky, quick, and the vine breaks, leaving a piece of itself sna under her skin. Stacy starts to SCREAM: STACY (cont'd) Get the knifes Eric is too shocked to stir. He's staring down at her leg at the bulge beneath her skin: it looks as if it's moving
Stacy's SCREAMING continues. Jeff and Amy are on their fe hurrying across the clearing. Mathias has opened his eyes
Get the knife! Jeff bends, scoops up the knife, starts toward the tent. waves toward Mathias.
Stay with him. Then he ducks in through the tent's flap. 77.

Eric is beside Stacy, trying to calm her; she's started t CRY. Her hands and wrists have turned a dark red, and the tendril is inside her leg, just to the left of her shin, running parallel to it. Jeff steps. toward them.
What is it?
The vine. It's inside her. Stacy points to her wound, SOBBING now:
Cut it out. You gotta cut it out.
The blade's dirty. We should-- Stacy starts shaking her head, FRANTIC:

It's moving! Can't you see? Jeff stares at the bulge, hesitating. Then it moves, unquestionably: contracting and expanding, like a worm. Stacy SHRIEKS: STACY (cont'd) Jeff! Be gives in, crouching over her leg.
It's gonna hurt.

Please. Hurry. He leans forward, slices into the skin above the bulge. Stacy CRIES OUT, starts to jerk away, but Jeff presses do on her leg, holding her still. He reaches into her wound with his finger, digs out the piece of vine, tosses it as

Get me a shirt or something. He gestures toward the backpacks, and Eric unzips one of them, starts to dig through it. 78. He pulls out a T-shirt, hands it to Jeff. Jeff wads it up uses it to put pressure on the incision, staunching the f of blood.
Amy is crouched by the backboard, watching the tent, tryi to grasp what's happening. Mathias startles her by speaki
Something's... wrong... His voice is thick-sounding, very faint. Amy tries to soo him; she puts her hand on his shoulder.
It's okay. It's just--
my-legs...
I know. You're hurt. But we're., gonna get you--
Show ...me... He's struggling to rise, straining upward. Amy tries to s him, pressing down on his shoulder.

Shh. But he fights her; he won't be quieted: MATHIAS. Show-me... So she leans, lifts the sleeping bag off him. His lower l are completely covered by the flowering vine, from the kn down. Amy and Mathias both stare in surprise. Then Amy reaches, starts to yank the tendrils free.
Jeff is leaning forward, pressing the balled-up T-shirt against Stacy's wound, the blood darkening the fabric. St is lying there, her eyes shut, fists clenched.
I can still feel it. 79. Jeff shakes his head.
I got it out.
I can feel it moving.
That's just your body. Your muscle twitching.

It's on our clothes. Stacy and Jeff both glance at him. There's a faint, almos fungus-like green growing on his shirt, an infantile vers of the vine covering the hillside all around them.
